sen.j: 貝合わせ（かいあわせ）は、平安時代から伝わる遊び。
sen.e: Kaiawase is a traditional game from Heian period.
Kaiawase is a traditional game from the Heian period.
Kaiawase is a traditional game from the Heian period.

sen.j: 本来の貝合わせは、合わせものの一つとして貝殻の色合いや形の美しさ、珍しさを競ったり、その貝を題材にした歌を詠んでその優劣を競い合ったりする貴族たちの遊びであった。
sen.e: Originally, kaiawase was played among nobilities as a kind of awasemono (games in which people gather each bringing something of the same kind to decide which is better) in competition for the beautiful coloring, shape, and rarity of the shells, or the superiority of uta (poetry) composed with the shell itself as its subject matter.

Originally, kaiawase was played among nobilities as a kind of awasemono (games in which people gather each bringing something of the same kind to decide which is better) in competition for the beautiful coloring, shape, and rarity of the shells, or the superiority of uta (poetry) composed with the shell itself as its subject matter.

Originally, kaiawase was played among nobilities as a kind of awasemono (games in which people gather each bringing something of the same kind to decide which is better) in competition for the beautiful coloring, shape, and rarity of the shells, or the superiority of uta (poetry) composed with the shell itself as its subject matter.

sen.j: 一方、「神経衰弱 (トランプ)」に似たゲームとしての貝合わせは貝覆いと呼ばれていたが、殻を合わせる所作から後に混同されて、同じく貝合わせと呼ばれるようになった。
sen.e: On the other hand, kaiawase as a game similar to the card game 'Concentration' used to be called "kaioi", but it later became mixed up with the other one because of its hand movement of putting shells together, and came to be called by the same name of kaiawase.
sen.cmt: 原文には（トランプ）とありますが、リンク先のようです。訳出不要かもしれませんが、分かりやすくするため文中に"the card game"と入れました。
sen.e: On the other hand, kaiawase as a game similar to the card game 'Concentration' used to be called "kaioi," but it later became mixed up with the other one because of its hand movement of putting shells together, and came to be called by the same name of kaiawase.

On the other hand, kaiawase as a game similar to the card game 'Concentration' used to be called "kaioi," but it later became mixed up with the other one because of its hand movement of putting shells together, and came to be called by the same name of kaiawase.

sen.j: 貝覆いの遊び方
sen.e: How to play Kaioi
How to play kaioi
sen.cmt: 表記統一のため、Kaioiの頭文字を小文字に変更
sen.e: How to play kaioi

sen.j: 貝覆いの貝は女性の掌中に握るのに適した大きさの、伊勢国二見産ハマグリを用いた。
sen.e: The shells used for kaioi were clams caught in Futami, Ise Province, which were suitable in size for women holding in their hands.
The shells used for kaioi were clams caught in Futami, Ise Province, which were suitable in size for women holding in their hands.
The shells used for kaioi were clams caught in Futami, Ise Province, which were suitable in size for women holding in their hands.

sen.j: 殻の内面には紙を貼り、源氏などの絵をかき、金箔などで極彩色に仕上げ、左右一対の殻には同じ絵を描いた。
sen.e: Inside of the shell was pasted with paper, on which they drew a picture on the theme of Genji (The Tale of Genji) or the like, then it was finished up with gold leaves and others to give it a brilliant coloring, and a pair of shells were both painted with the same picture.

Inside of the shell was pasted with paper, on which they drew a picture on the theme of Genji (The Tale of Genji) or the like, then it was finished up with gold leaves and others to give it a brilliant coloring, and a pair of shells were both painted with the same picture.

A piece of paper was pasted on the inner surface of the shell, on which they drew a picture on the theme of Genji (The Tale of Genji) or the like, then finished it up with gold leaves and others to give it a brilliant coloring; the same picture was painted on each shell of the pair.
sen.cmt: Inside the shell was pasted a piece of paper→A piece of paper was pasted on the inner surface of the shell a pair of shells were both painted with the same picture→the same picture was paintedi on each shell of the pair

sen.j: 貝は耳の短い方を前にして、頂を自分の方に向けると、右が出し貝すなわち陰、左が地貝すなわち陽である。
sen.e: When the shorter ear of the shell faces you, if you turn the umbo toward yourself, Dashigai (clamshells which are put in the bucket and later taken out one by one to play kaioi) as yin (passive) is on the right, and Jigai (clamshells which are placed on the mat in kaioi) as yang (active) is on the left.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: When the shorter ear of the shell faces you, if you turn the umbo toward yourself, dashigai (clamshells which are put in the bucket and later taken out one by one to play kaioi) as yin (passive) is on the right, and jigai (clamshells which are placed on the mat in kaioi) as yang (active) is on the left.
sen.cmt: 表記統一のため、Dashigai→dashigai、Jigai→jigaiとしました。
sen.e: When the shorter ear of the shell faces you, if you turn the umbo toward yourself, dashigai (clamshells which are put in the bucket and later taken out one by one to play kaioi) as yin (passive) is on the right, and jigai (clamshells which are placed on the mat in kaioi) as yang (active) is on the left.

sen.j: これを天地に象（かたど）り、男女に付会し、別々の貝桶におさめた。
sen.e: The pair, which represent heaven and earth, and are also compared to man and woman, were stored in separate kaioke (a bucket filled with clamshells).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The pair, which represent heaven and earth, and are also compared to man and woman, were stored in separate kaioke (a bucket filled with clamshells).
The pair, which represent heaven and earth, and are also compared to man and woman, were stored in separate kaioke (a bucket filled with clamshells).

sen.j: 天文暦学等に関連せしめて、遊びの方法が定められた。
sen.e: The rules of the game were developed with reference to the study of astronomical almanac and others.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The rules of the game were developed with reference to the study of astronomical almanac and others.
The rules of the game were developed with reference to the study of astronomical almanac and others.

sen.j: 天にかたどった地貝の伏せ方は、まず中央に12ヶ月にかたどって12個を伏せ、7曜日にかたどってしだいに7個をくわえ、1年の日数にかたどった360個のハマグリ殻を過不足無く9列にならべる。
sen.e: Jigai as heaven are put inside down, starting with 12 of them in the center representing 12 months, then 7 shells as the days of the week are added, and finally, exactly 360 clamshells representing the days of a year are arranged in 9 rows.
sen.cmt: 原文にある「しだいに」の意味が定かではありませんが、「次に」と解釈しました。
sen.e: Jigai as heaven are put inside down, starting with 12 of them in the center representing 12 months, then 7 shells as the days of the week are added, and finally, exactly 360 clamshells representing the days of a year are arranged in 9 rows.

Jigai as heaven are put inside down, starting with 12 of them in the center representing 12 months, then 7 shells as the days of the week are added, and finally, exactly 360 clamshells representing the days of a year are arranged in 9 rows.

sen.j: 9列であるのは昔の天文学で天を九重と考えたからであるという。
sen.e: It is said that 9 rows are based on old-time astronomy in which heaven were considered ninefold.
It is said that 9 rows are based on old-time astronomy in which heaven were considered ninefold.
It is said that 9 rows are based on old-time astronomy in which heaven were considered ninefold.

sen.j: すなわち口が12、次が19とある。
sen.e: Starting with 12, then 19.
Starting with 12, then 19.
Starting with 12, then 19.

sen.j: この19という数は暦学上重要な数であり陽暦も陰暦も19箇年で一循環するという。
sen.e: 19 is the important number in the study of calendars, and both the solar and lunar calendar take 19 years to complete a full circle.
19 is the important number in the study of calendars, and both the solar and lunar calendars take 19 years to complete a full circle.
19 is the important number in the study of calendars, and both the solar and lunar calendars take 19 years to complete a full circle.

sen.j: 地貝を立て終ると、出役の女房が出貝桶から出貝1個を取り出し、中央に伏せる。
sen.e: When all jigai are set, nyobo (a court lady) as dashiyaku (a person who picks out dashigai) takes one of dashigai out of dashigaioke (kaioke for dashigai) and put it inside down on the center.
When all jigai are set, nyobo (a court lady) as dashiyaku (a person who picks out dashigai) takes one of dashigai out of dashigaioke (kaioke for dashigai) and put it inside down on the center.
When all jigai are set, nyobo (a court lady) as dashiyaku (a person who picks out dashigai) takes one of dashigai out of dashigaioke (kaioke for dashigai) and put it inside down on the center.

sen.j: 周囲に並んだ20人以上の姫君方が、360の地貝に斑紋や形状等の出貝と全く同じものを見定める。
sen.e: More than 20 himegimi (daughter of a person of high rank) surrounding the shells try to find only one jigai, out of 360, with exactly the same spots and shape as dashigai.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: More than 20 himegimi (daughter of a person of high rank) surrounding the shells try to find only one jigai, out of 360, with exactly the same spots and shape as dashigai.
More than 20 himegimi (daughter of a person of high rank) surrounding the shells try to find only one jigai, out of 360, with exactly the same spots and shape as dashigai.

sen.j: そしておもむろに1対のハマグリ殻を掌中に取り上げ、片手で合わせ、よくあったならば、2つにわけて膝の前に伏せる。
sen.e: Someone calmly takes up a pair of clamshells in her hand, and if they match perfectly in one hand, she separates the pair and put them inside down in front of her knees.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Someone calmly takes up a pair of clamshells in her hand, and if they match perfectly in one hand, she separates the pair and put them inside down in front of her knees.
Someone calmly takes up a pair of clamshells in her hand, and if they match perfectly in one hand, she separates the pair and put them inside down in front of her knees.

sen.j: 出役が出貝を中心に伏せると、また同じことを繰り返し、最も多く取った者が勝である。
sen.e: Then dashiyaku put another dashigai on the center and they repeat the same thing again and again, and the player with the most shells should be the winner.
Then dashiyaku put another dashigai on the center and they repeat the same thing again and again, and the player with the most shells should be the winner.
Then dashiyaku put another dashigai on the center and they repeat the same thing again and again, and the player with the most shells should be the winner.

sen.j: 幾度も間違えることは恥辱であるとされ、おのずと修身の具ともなり、明治維新前までは貝桶が上流社会の嫁入り道具の一であったという。
sen.e: Because making many mistakes in the game are considered shameful, kaioi became a means to learn morals and kaioke had been one of a bride's household articles in high society until the Meiji Restoration.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「修身の具」とは修身を象徴する「物」なのか、修身を学ぶ「手段」なのか迷いましたが、後者をとりました。
sen.e: Because making many mistakes in the game were considered shameful, kaioi became a means to learn morals and kaioke had been one of a bride's household articles in high society until the Meiji Restoration.

Because making many mistakes in the game were considered shameful, kaioi became a means to learn morals and kaioke had been one of a bride's household articles in high society until the Meiji Restoration.

sen.j: しかし近代以降は遊ばれることもなく、実物の貝覆いの道具一式は博物館などで見られる程度であるが、雛人形にはミニチュアの貝桶などが今なお残っているのを見ることがある。
sen.e: Kaioi has not been played anymore in and after modern times, and now a real, complete set of kaioi can be seen only in museums, but some hinaningyo (a set of dolls displayed for the Girls' Festival) still has miniature kaioke and other articles.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Kaioi has not been played anymore in and after modern times, and now a real, complete set of kaioi can be seen only in museums, but some hinaningyo (a set of dolls displayed for the Girls' Festival) still has miniature kaioke and other articles.

Kaioi has not been played anymore in and after modern times, and now a real, complete set of kaioi can be seen only in museums, but some hinaningyo (a set of dolls displayed for the Girls' Festival) still has miniature kaioke and other articles.

sen.j: 江戸時代の貝合わせ
sen.e: Kaiawase of Edo period
Kaiawase in the Edo period
sen.cmt: of Edo period→in the Edo periodとしました。
sen.e: Kaiawase in the Edo period

sen.j: 江戸時代の貝合わせは、内側を蒔絵や金箔で装飾されたハマグリの貝殻を使用する。
sen.e: For kaiawase of Edo period, they used clamshells with makie (Japanese lacquer sprinkled with gold or silver powder) or gold-leaf decoration inside.
For kaiawase in the Edo period, they used clamshells with makie (Japanese lacquer sprinkled with gold or silver powder) or gold-leaf decoration inside.
sen.cmt: of Edo period→in the Edo periodとしました。
sen.e: For kaiawase in the Edo period, they used clamshells with makie (Japanese lacquer sprinkled with gold or silver powder) or gold-leaf decoration inside.

sen.j: ハマグリなどの二枚貝は、対となる貝殻としか組み合わせることができないので、裏返した貝殻のペアを選ぶようにして遊んだ。
sen.e: Bivalves such as clams will not match any shell other than their counterpart, so people played kaiawase choosing a pair out of the shells placed face down.
Bivalves such as clams would not match any shell other than their counterpart, so people played kaiawase choosing a pair out of the shells placed face down.
Bivalves such as clams would not match any shell other than their counterpart, so people played kaiawase choosing a pair out of the shells placed face down.

sen.j: また、対になる貝を違えないところから夫婦和合の象徴とされた。
sen.e: Because the shells don't change their partner, they became a symbol of conjugal harmony.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Because the shells did not change their partner, they became a symbol of conjugal harmony.
Because the shells did not change their partner, they became a symbol of conjugal harmony.

sen.j: 公家や大名家の嫁入り道具の美しい貝桶や貝が作られた。
sen.e: Kuge (court noble) and Daimyo (feudal lord) family prepared beautiful kaioke and shells for their daughter as the bride's household articles.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Kuge (court noble) and Daimyo (feudal lord) family prepared beautiful kaioke and shells for their daughter as the bride's household articles.
Kuge (court noble) and Daimyo (feudal lord) family prepared beautiful kaioke and shells for their daughter as the bride's household articles.

sen.j: 貝の内側に描かれるのは自然の風物や土佐一門風の公家の男女が多かった。
sen.e: On the inside of a shell, natural features or a couple who look like of kuge family in Tosa clan are often depicted.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処「土佐一門風の公家」が具体的にどのような人を指すのか判断できませんでしたが、左のように訳しました。
sen.e: On the inside of a shell, natural features or a court couple who looked like the Tosa clan were often depicted.
sen.cmt: look→looked、are→wereに修正、a couple who look like of kuge family in Tosa clan→a court couple who looked like the Tosa clanとしました。
sen.e: On the inside of a shell, natural features or a court couple who looked like the Tosa clan were often depicted.

sen.j: 対になる貝には同じく対になる絵が描かれた。
sen.e: A pair of shells carried a matching pair of pictures.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: A pair of shells carried a matching pair of pictures.
A pair of shells carried a matching pair of pictures.

sen.j: 美しく装飾された合貝を納めた貝桶は八角形の形をしており二個一対であった。
sen.e: Octagonal kaioke filled with beautifully decorated awasegai (shells for kaiawase) were made in pairs.
Octagonal kaioke filled with beautifully decorated awasegai (shells for kaiawase) were made in pairs.
Octagonal kaioke filled with beautifully decorated awasegai (shells for kaiawase) were made in pairs.

sen.j: 大名家の姫の婚礼調度の中で最も重要な意味を持ち、婚礼行列の際には先頭で運ばれた。
sen.e: They were the most important article of the bride's household effects for a daimyo's daughter, so that they were carried at the head of a wedding procession.
They were the most important article of the bride's household effects for a daimyo's daughter, so that they were carried at the head of a wedding procession.
They were the most important article of the bride's household effects for a daimyo's daughter, so that they were carried at the head of a wedding procession.

sen.j: 婚礼行列が婚家に到着すると、まず初めに貝桶を新婦側から婚家側に引き渡す｢貝桶渡し｣の儀式が行われた。
sen.e: After the procession arrived in a bridegroom's residence, 'kaioke watashi' was conducted as the first ritual, in which kaioke was handed over from the bride's side to the groom's side.
After the procession arrived in a bridegroom's residence, 'kaioke watashi' was conducted as the first ritual, in which kaioke was handed over from the bride's side to the groom's side.
After the procession arrived in a bridegroom's residence, 'kaioke watashi' was conducted as the first ritual, in which kaioke was handed over from the bride's side to the groom's side.

sen.j: 貝桶渡しは家老などの重臣が担当し、大名家の婚礼に置いて重要な儀式であった。
sen.e: Karo (chief retainer of a feudal lord) or other senior vassals performed kaioke watashi as the most important ritual in a wedding ceremony of daimyo families.
sen.cmt: 原文「置いて」は、「於いて」の誤りと思われます。
sen.e: Karo (chief retainer of a feudal lord) or other senior vassals performed kaioke watashi as the most important ritual in a wedding ceremony of daimyo families.
Karo (chief retainer of a feudal lord) or other senior vassals performed kaioke watashi as the most important ritual in a wedding ceremony of daimyo families.
